'''Texas Johnny Brown''' (February 22, 1928 - July 1, 2013) was an [[United States|American]] blues guitarist, songwriter and singer.  He is best known for his composition "Two Steps from the Blues" and, in a lengthy career, variously worked with [[Joe Hinton]], [[Amos Milburn]], [[Ruth Brown]], [[Bobby Bland|Bobby "Blue" Bland]], [[Lavelle White]], [[Buddy Ace]] and [[Junior Parker]].<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://www.thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2013b.html#sthash.9nGhXT1h.YcaIKT1M.dpbs |title=July to December |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref> Although he was born in [[Mississippi]], Brown's long association with [[Houston]], [[Texas]], gave him his [[stage name]].

Before his death, [[Allmusic]] noted that Brown "remains one of the more immovable veterans dotting the inexplicably low-key Houston blues landscape".<ref>{{cite web|last=Rowland |first=Hobart |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/nothin-but-the-truth-mw0000990598 |title=Nothin' but the Truth - Texas Johnny Brown : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref> His jazzy guitar style of playing the blues, has been attested to the early influence on him of [[Charlie Christian]].<ref name="Chron"/>

==Biography==
He was born '''John Riley Brown''',<ref name="Dead"/> in [[Ackerman, Mississippi|Ackerman]], [[Choctaw County, Mississippi|Choctaw County]], [[Mississippi]], United States. As a child he played guitar alongside his father, who was blinded while working for the railroad,<ref name="Valley"/> on the streets of his hometown and further afield, before the family finally relocated to Houston in 1946.<ref name="Chron"/><ref name="Dansby">{{cite news|last=Dansby |first=Andrew |url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/entertainment/music/article/Texas-Johnny-Brown-gigged-till-the-end-4643619.php |title='Texas' Johnny Brown gigged till the end |newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date= |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref>

Brown's professional music career started in a band called the Aladdin Chickenshackers, who regularly backed [[Amos Milburn]].<ref name="AMG"/>  He recorded with Milburn, and also backed [[Ruth Brown]] on her earliest cuts for [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]].  Through this work, in 1949, Brown was able to record some tracks of his own, where he was in turn backed by Milburn and the Aladdin Chickenshackers.<ref name="Choctaw">{{cite web|url=http://www.choctawcreekrecords.com/tjb.html |title=Texas Johnny Brown |publisher=Choctaw Creek Records |date= |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref>  He also undertook an unreleased session for the [[American Record Corporation]] in the early 1950s.<ref name="AMG"/>  Brown's three year stint of [[military service]] finished in 1953, and he re-commenced backing [[Lightnin' Hopkins]].<ref>{{cite book
| first= Alan B.
| last= Govenar
| year= 2010
| title= Lightnin' Hopkins: His Life and Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[Chicago Review Press]] 
| location= [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] 
| isbn= 978-1-55652-962-7
| page= 62}}</ref> In addition, Brown performed regularly with [[Junior Parker]] throughout the 1950s.<ref name="Choctaw"/> 

Brown's recording career continued in the mid 1950s, when he was utilised mainly as a [[sideman]] for both of the affiliated [[Duke Records|Duke]] and [[Peacock Records|Peacock]] [[record label]]s.  Often his contributions went uncredited on releases by musicians such as Lightnin' Hopkins and [[Joe Hinton]].<ref name="AMG"/> In the late 1950s, Brown composed "Two Steps from the Blues", which became the title of an album released by [[Bobby Bland|Bobby "Blues" Bland]] in 1961.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Charles
| last= Farley
| year= 2011
| title= Soul of the Man: Bobby "Blue" Bland
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[University Press of Mississippi]] 
| location= [[Jackson, Mississippi]] 
| isbn= 978-1-60473-919-0
| pages= 90/1}}</ref>  Brown toured as Bland's lead guitarist in the 1950s and 1960s.<ref name="AMG"/>

Brown continued with his regular recording and stage duties until 1963, when he began a number of day jobs including driving trucks, working as a mechanic,<ref name="Valley"/> landscaping and operating a forklift.<ref name="Dansby"/> Brown also recalled [[jam session]]s in the mid 1960s at the Club Matinee in Houston, which regularly featured himself, [[Goree Carter]], Joe Bell, [[Roy Gaines]] and Clarence Hollimon.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Charles Roger
| last= Wood
| year= 2003
| title= Down in Houston - Bayou City Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[University of Texas Press]] 
| location= [[Austin, Texas]] 
| isbn= 0-292-79159-3
| page= 164}}</ref> He retired in 1991, and formed the Quality Blues Band with whom he performed up to his death.<ref name="Dansby"/> His 1949 tracks, "The Blues Rock", "There Goes The Blues", and "Bongo Boogie" were featured on the [[compilation album]], ''Atlantic Blues:Guitar'', which was first released by Atlantic Records in 1986.<ref name="Choctaw"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/mctelfrm.htm |title=Blind Willie McTell discography |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref>

In 1996, Brown appeared at the [[Long Beach Blues Festival]].<ref name="Choctaw"/> In 1998, Brown finally released an album under his own name, ''Nothin' but the Truth''.  The [[Allmusic]] [[music journalism|journalist]], Hobart Rowland noted of the tracks, "the insistent toe-tappers 'Your House, Your Home' and 'Stand the Pain' and the keyboard-drenched 'Blue and Lonesome' are easily among Brown's best".<ref name="Nothin'">{{cite web|last=Rowland |first=Hobart |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/nothin-but-the-truth-mw0000990598 |title=Nothin' but the Truth - Texas Johnny Brown : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref> ''Nothin' but the Truth'', which included Brown's version of his song "Two Steps from the Blues", was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award|W.C. Handy Blues Award]] in 1999 as the 'Comeback Album of the Year'.<ref name="Choctaw"/><ref name="Brown">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.txjohnnybrown.com/ |title=RIP |publisher=Txjohnnybrown.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref>

In September 2001, Brown was named 'Blues Artist of the Year' at the Willie Mae "Big Mama" Thornton Blues Festival, which took place in Houston.<ref name="Choctaw"/> In January 2002, Brown's second album, ''Blues Defender'' was released, also on Choctaw Creek Records.<ref name="Defender">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/blues-defender-mw0000213165 |title=Blues Defender - Texas Johnny Brown : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2002-01-22 |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref> Brown was quoted following an interview in June 2010 with the Texan newspaper, ''[[Valley Morning Star]]'', about his work that, "melancholy feelings make good blues music."<ref name="Valley">{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.valleymorningstar.com/news/local_news/article_1492d528-e38e-11e2-b6e9-0019bb30f31a.html |title=Popular blues musician dies at 85 |newspaper=[[Valley Morning Star]] |date=2013-07-02 |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref>

In September 2011, Brown's roots were honored with an historical marker on the [[Mississippi Blues Trail]] in Ackerman.<ref name="Chron">{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/life/article/Mississippi-honors-Houston-s-Texas-Johnny-Brown-2151584.php |title=Mississippi honors Houston's Texas Johnny Brown - ''Houston Chronicle'' |publisher=Chron.com |date=2011-09-01 |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref>

Brown died at his home in Houston, Texas, in July 2013 from [[lung cancer]], aged 85.<ref name="Dead"/><ref name="Brown"/>
